title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the profit-maximizing quantity as 3 units and/or does not explain that the 3rd unit is the last unit where the marginal revenue ($40) is greater than the marginal cost ($35); the firm will not produce the 4th unit because the marginal cost of producing it ($45) is greater than the marginal revenue earned ($40).

The response identifies the profit-maximizing quantity as 3 units and explains that the 3rd unit is the last unit where the marginal revenue ($40) is greater than the marginal cost ($35); the firm will not produce the 4th unit because the marginal cost of producing it ($45) is greater than the marginal revenue earned ($40).

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the number of firms in the industry will decrease and/or does not explain negative economic profit will cause firms to exit the industry.
The response states that the number of firms in the industry will decrease and explains that negative economic profit will cause firms to exit the industry.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the market price will increase and/or does not explain that with the exit of firms, the market supply will decrease, causing the price to increase.
The response states that the market price will increase and explains that with the exit of firms, the market supply will decrease, causing the price to increase.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the demand for basketballs will decrease and/or does not explain that the negative cross-price elasticity of demand for basketballs with respect to the price of Good Y means that the goods are complements; therefore, an increase in the price of Good Y will lead to a decrease in the demand for basketballs.

The response states that that demand for basketballs will decrease and explains that the negative cross-price elasticity of demand for basketballs with respect to the price of Good Y means that the goods are complements; therefore, an increase in the price of Good Y will lead to a decrease in the demand for basketballs.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does none of the following:

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good Y will stay the same in the short run and explains that a change in fixed cost does not affect the marginal cost.

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good Y will increase and explains that a decrease in the market wage will decrease the wage the firm pays its workers because the firm is a wage-taker in a perfectly competitive market; wages are a variable cost, so a decrease in the wage will shift the marginal cost curve downward at each quantity so that marginal cost will intersect marginal revenue at a higher quantity.

The response does one of the following:

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good Y will stay the same in the short run and explains that a change in fixed cost does not affect the marginal cost.

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good Y will increase and explains that a decrease in the market wage will decrease the wage the firm pays its workers because the firm is a wage-taker in a perfectly competitive market; wages are a variable cost, so a decrease in the wage will shift the marginal cost curve downward at each quantity so that marginal cost will intersect marginal revenue at a higher quantity.

The response does both of the following:

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good Y will stay the same in the short run and explains that a change in fixed cost does not affect the marginal cost.

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good Y will increase and explains that a decrease in the market wage will decrease the wage the firm pays its workers because the firm is a wage-taker in a perfectly competitive market; wages are a variable cost, so a decrease in the wage will shift the marginal cost curve downward at each quantity so that marginal cost will intersect marginal revenue at a higher quantity.
